title: How to Accept Yourself as LGBT

steps.title: Look for the answers to questions you have about your LGBTQ+ identity.
steps.content: Look for the answers to questions you have about your LGBTQ+ identity. When you first realize that you may be LGBTQ+, it’s normal to have questions. Learning about sexuality and what it means to be LGBTQ+ may help you answer these questions. Read online resources to help you recognize that being LGBTQ+ is part of who you are and there’s nothing wrong with it. [1] X Research source For instance, you might worry that being sexually attracted to the same sex is unhealthy, but it’s actually just as healthy as being straight. [2] X Trustworthy Source American Psychological Association Leading scientific and professional organization of licensed psychologists Go to source

steps.title: Keep a journal
steps.content: Keep a journal to help you work through your feelings. Writing down your thoughts and feelings helps you process them. Journal every day or when you’re feeling conflicted. Include both your positive and negative experiences to help you remember that life includes both ups and downs. [3] X Trustworthy Source University of Rochester Medical Center Leading academic medical center in the U.S. focused on clinical care and research Go to source Re-read your journal periodically to see how far you’ve come.

steps.title: Talk to someone you trust when you’re struggling, if possible.
steps.content: Talk to someone you trust when you’re struggling, if possible. You don’t need to come out if you’re not ready. However, it helps to vent your feelings to someone who cares about you. Talk to a trusted friend or family member when you’re feeling overwhelmed. Tell them as much as you’re comfortable sharing. This might help you feel better. [4] X Research source You might say, “Right now I’m feeling really conflicted about something. I’m not comfortable talking about all of it, but I really need a friend right now.”

steps.title: Recognize that you are normal and can live a very happy life.
steps.content: Recognize that you are normal and can live a very happy life. Members of the LGBTQ+ community find partners, have families, thrive in their careers, and can enjoy all of life's ups and downs just like anyone else. Watch coming out stories on YouTube, as well as read coming out advice on the internet. Being LGBTQ+ is part of your identity, and you were born this way. You deserve to live a happy life as your authentic self! [5] X Research source While you might have negative experiences because of your identity, it’s important to remember that you’ll also have positive experiences. Try to focus on the good things in your life instead of the bad things.

steps.title: Give yourself as much time as you need to label your identity.
steps.content: Give yourself as much time as you need to label your identity. Don’t feel rushed to label yourself as LGBTQ+ or to choose a specific sexuality, such as bisexual. Take as much time as you need to decide which labels you prefer if you want to use any. When you’re ready, decide what feels right to you and know that you can change it at anytime. [6] X Research source For instance, you might decide that you think you’re bisexual. However, it’s okay to decide later that you’re gay. It’s totally okay to change your label.

steps.title: See a therapist if you’re having trouble processing your feelings.
steps.content: See a therapist if you’re having trouble processing your feelings. If you’re having trouble accepting yourself, it may help to see a therapist. Your therapist can help you process your thoughts and feelings. They’ll also help you learn how to accept and love yourself. Ask your doctor to refer you to a therapist or look for one online. [7] X Research source You may be able to find a therapist who is also LGBTQ+. Your therapy appointments may be covered by insurance, so check your benefits.

steps.title: Release self judgement
steps.content: Release self judgement to find peace with yourself. You might be having trouble accepting your identity because of what you’ve been taught about it. This is really common, and it’s hard to overcome. Confront the judgments you’re making about yourself with loving kindness and facts about LGBTQ+ identity. Approach yourself with kindness and acceptance of who you are. [8] X Research source For instance, you may have been taught that being LGBTQ+ is a sin. While some people believe that, more and more people are starting to understand that sexuality and gender are naturally fluid.

steps.title: Attend a pro-LGBTQ+ event to help you feel positive about your identity.
steps.content: Attend a pro-LGBTQ+ event to help you feel positive about your identity. Meeting other people in the LGBTQ+ community might help you feel more comfortable with your sexuality. Start going to events as an ally until you’re ready to come out of the closet. Talk to the people you meet and learn about their experiences. Spend more time around people who make you feel positive about being LGBTQ+. [9] X Research source If you feel comfortable, share with them that you’re also LGBTQ+ or questioning but that you’re not out yet. For instance, you might attend a Pride event, a Meetup for the LGBTQ+ community, or a support group.

steps.title: Build a support network of people who build you up.
steps.content: Build a support network of people who build you up. A good support network will include friends, family, and other members of the LGBTQ+ community. Choose people who accept you as you are and boost your mood. Spend time with your support network to remind yourself that you’re loved. [10] X Research source You might be able to find friends by attending LGBTQ+ events and businesses, including Pride. If you’re religious or spiritual, look for a community that supports who you are. You may be able to find a religious leader in your faith who is open to everyone, including LGBTQ+ people.

steps.title: Minimize the time you spend with people who don’t accept you.
steps.content: Minimize the time you spend with people who don’t accept you. Unfortunately, some of your friends and family members may refuse to accept your LGBTQ+ identity. This can be super painful, but it’s important to remember that it’s not your fault. When possible, remove these individuals from your life so that their negativity doesn’t bring you down. If the person is a loved one, limit your visits with them. [11] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source For instance, let’s say your aunt refuses to accept your identity. You might choose to see her only at holiday events.

steps.title: Follow social media accounts that feature pro-LGBTQ+ content.
steps.content: Follow social media accounts that feature pro-LGBTQ+ content. Look for accounts that interest you and hit follow. Seeing posts from others LGBTQ+ people reminds you that you aren’t alone. Additionally, it may help you learn more about what it means to be LGBTQ+ and how you can live your best life. Scroll through their posts when you need a boost. [12] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source If someone's content makes you feel uncomfortable or is divisive, remember that you can unfollow, report, or block their content.

steps.title: Enjoy pro-LGBTQ+ movies, TV shows, and books.
steps.content: Enjoy pro-LGBTQ+ movies, TV shows, and books. Fortunately, you can find a wide array of content that features LGBTQ+ characters. This can help you realize that your experiences are common and it’s okay to celebrate who you are. Look for content that features characters you like and identify with. [13] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Ignore content that mocks the LGBTQ+ community or focuses on stereotypes. You don't need that kind of negativity in your life!

steps.title: Come out
steps.content: Come out to friends and family when you’re ready. Take as long as you need to feel comfortable coming out. When you feel the time is right, tell your closest friends and family members. Then, share your sexual identity with everyone else. Make the coming out process about you and do what makes you feel comfortable. [14] X Research source You might choose to tell a few people at a time, or you may decide to host a big party or post it on social media so everyone finds out at once. If you’re not ready to come out, try coming out on an online support network. Be sure to use a screen name for safety purposes. Don’t come out if it puts your health or safety at risk. If your parents or the person supporting you may be potentially abusive or might kick you out of the house, don’t tell them until you’re in a safe situation. Reader Poll: We asked 1270 wikiHow readers to tell us how they would respond if someone reacted negatively to them coming out, and only 8% agreed they would ask someone close to them to help change their mind. [Take Poll] So, while that may not be a great strategy according to our readers, try to give them time to digest the news on their own terms.

steps.title: Be yourself and ignore the stereotypes.
steps.content: Be yourself and ignore the stereotypes. Unfortunately, there are a lot of stereotypes about what it means to be LGBTQ+. However, there’s no one way to be. Dress however you like, walk and talk in a way that feels comfortable to you, and love who you want. Your life is yours, and you don’t need to model yourself after someone else to be part of the LGBTQ+ community. [15] X Research source As an example, you might have seen stereotypes of gay men as feminine, and lesbian women as butch. Similarly, you might think of trans women as dressing a certain way. All of this is stereotyping, and it’s not a true reflection of how all real, everyday LGBTQ+ people live.

steps.title: Participate in pride events to celebrate who you are.
steps.content: Participate in pride events to celebrate who you are. June is Pride Month in the United States, but you may find pride events at other times of the year and in other places. Pride helps you remember that being LGBTQ+ isn’t something to hide or be ashamed about. It’s who you are, and you deserve to feel loved and accepted. Look for pride events near you so that you can celebrate being LGBTQ+. [16] X Research source It’s fun to dress up for pride, but you can also wear normal street clothes. Pick what makes you feel comfy.

steps.title: Participate in pro-LGBTQ+ activism if you feel ready.
steps.content: Participate in pro-LGBTQ+ activism if you feel ready. While the LGBTQ+ community is making great strides in gaining equal rights and acceptance, there’s still a lot of work to do, especially from a global aspect. When you feel ready, consider becoming an activist. There are tons of ways you can help. Here are some ideas: [17] X Research source Donate to activist groups. Volunteer for an activist group. Write your lawmaker to promote pro-LGBTQ+ issues. Join or lead a protest against discrimination. Write for pro-LGBTQ+ publications. Educate the people in your life about LGBTQ+ issues.
